There was growing widespread disillusionment, uncertainty,

So, in the west, for the last couple years now,
minimalism has been on its way out
and maximalism has been on its way in.
What do I mean by these terms?
Well, according to the Museum of FIT's
minimalism-slash-maximalism exhibition,
"minimalism refers to the aesthetic of less is more,
it celebrates purity and restraint,
promoting qualities such as truth, order and harmony.
Minimalist fashions prioritize reduction and function,
using clean lines and silhouettes
to accentuate the relationship between body and garment.
On the other hand, maximalism refers to spectacle.
Its beauty lies in excess and eclecticism.
Throughout history, maximalist fashions
have been associated with extravagant,
artifice, and nonfunctional style.
As a journalistic term,
maximalism is often used in reference
to audacious, intricate aesthetics
or exaggerated silhouettes."
For the last 100 years or so, or maybe longer,
there's been this natural pendulum swing
between maximalism and minimalism.
In the 80s, for instance, maximalism was all the rage
with voluminous silhouettes and bold colors.
It was all about ostentatious glamor.
Pioneering designers of the time include Thierry Mugler
and Gianni Versace.
Then, in the 90s, the streamlined minimalist look came in,
with major contributions from Helmut Lang,
Martin Margiela, and Prada.
Also, as a response to the 80s excess of Wall Street,
grunge consumed youth culture.
The pendulum swung back to maximalism in the 2000s,
which borrowed from 1980s excess.
The Y2K party girl was messy and over the top.
Paris Hilton reigned supreme.
And there was no such thing as too many accessories.
Then, as Sir Isaac Newton says,
with every action is an equal and opposite reaction.
So back to minimalism in the 2010s.
Most fashion and lifestyle bloggers that were emerging
showcased their minimalist, modern homes,
Instagram feeds were monotone,

On the youth front, grunge was making a comeback

And now we're once again maximalist.

- There's a few different theoretical camps for maximalism.
Some people just throw any patterned color at the wall

there is one color palette

On a simpler front,

There's so much to look at that makes you smile.
Isn't that so much more interesting than a boring room
